text1: Confusion's cure lives not In these confusions .
text2: Confusion is a cure for confusion .

text1: He was my brother's son !
text2: He is my brother's son !

text1: Let them judge us however they please .
text2: How they choose to judge us , We shall judge them .

text1: Will you speak well of him that killed your cousin ?
text2: Did your cousin kill your cousin ?

text1: You , Prince , are the man who can give me justice .
text2: Prince , I am the one that can make you a justice .

text1: Calling death banishment is like cutting off my head with a golden ax and smiling while I'm being murdered .
text2: It is like I'll cut off my head with a golden axe And smile when I am slain .

text1: I am aweary .
text2: I'm a big man .

text1: Is the worst well ?
text2: Is the worst ?

text1: When and where and how We met , we wooed and made exchange of vow , I'll tell thee as we pass , but this I pray : That thou consent to marry us today .
text2: We met , we exchanged vows , and I beg you to marry us today .

text1: Tis well thou art not fish .
text2: You're not a fish , you're a fish .

text1: Take me inside some house , Benvolio , or I'll pass out .
text2: Go , Benvolio , I must go to the house .

text1: But to say that Tybalt's dead and then say , "Romeo has been banished." To say that is like saying that my father , my mother , Tybalt , Romeo , and Juliet have all been killed , they're all dead .
text2: They say that Tybalt was slain and then they say , "Romeo was slain ." They say , "They say that Tybalt

text1: And there she shall at Friar Lawrence ' cell Be shrived and married .
text2: She was taken to the cell of the friar Lawrence .

text1: Your husband lies dead there , and Paris too .
text2: Your husband is dead .

text1: And private in his chamber pens himself , Shuts up his windows , locks fair daylight out , And makes himself an artificial night .
text2: He locks the doors , locks the windows , and makes himself a night of artificial light .

text1: Your love says , like an honest gentleman , and a courteous , and a kind , and a handsome , and , I warrant , a virtuous , Where is your mother ?
text2: Your love is like a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman , a gentleman

text1: Despised , distressed , hated , martyred , killed !
text2: Disgusted , distressed , hated , slain !

text1: What a man , young lady .
text2: What a man is this , my dear lord .

text1: I am too sore enpierced with his shaft To soar with his light feathers , and so bound , I can not bound a pitch above dull woe .
text2: I'm too sore to fly with his light feathers , and so I'm bound to fall into a deep , dark hole .

text1: Well , sir , because silver has a sweet sound .
text2: Why , so , sir , silver is a sweet sound .

text1: Monday , my lord .
text2: My lord .

text1: I am sped .
text2: I'm going fast .

text1: Right , and well said .
text2: Well , and I say it well .
